Review title: Not a masterpiece, but decent enough.
Review_body: So this bizarre Once-ler obsession has been taking my home website of deviantART by storm, and finally I was thrust into watching "The Lorax," despite my strong personal objection. As the son of an environmental sciences professor, I have many strong feelings about Dr. Suess' The Lorax, having grown up with the original book and animation from oh so long ago. I have to admit, it is a cute, decent movie; nothing as terrible as I thought it was going to turn out. That said, it's no masterpiece, either.Plot: The plot was true enough to the story, with a few minor changes. Instead of focusing on the story of the Once-ler and his rise to power and ultimately failure, the new Lorax movie features the young boy as the primary. Or does it? This left me a little confused, as the fight for character dominance continues throughout the story, focusing partly on Ted (the boy) and partly on the Once-ler. I don't have a problem with duel leads, but in this case I felt as though it added nothing to the story, instead taking away from both characters chances to shine as the star. I did not understand the importance of O'Hare and his posse, or their attempts to foil Ted's exploits, but it seemed as though it must have been relevant. The Once-ler's story kept getting chopped into pieces (just like those poor truffula trees), to tell it.Characters: The characters in this movie are varied. Some, like the Once-ler and the Lorax (you would hope) were vivid, lively, and well-written. Others, I couldn't help but wonder what they were doing in the movie. I failed to see Audrey's role in the story, aside from providing a romance interest, and O'Hare and his lackeys did nothing but try to create problematic situations for young Ted, despite no true reason to do so. Obviously the star of the movie was the Once-ler, and I will admit, I was taken with his character. The "evil" outfit was perfect The use of colour, fantastic. They used the Once-ler's signature green gloves and the connotation of green as representative of greed, and black as lingering darkness to paint an awesome character. I can now see why he is so well-liked. That said, I found myself disliking the sympathetic portrait they painted of him, throughout. Not because I am against sympathetic characters, but because it goes against the original idea of the Once-ler. In the original, the Once-ler is a greedy man who doesn't see the error of his ways until it is much too late. He considers the notion a few times, but there is ultimately no guilt. In this, he is well aware of the harm he's creating and the promise he made—and broke—to the Lorax. In short, wonderful character, but perhaps the wrong place for him. The Lorax himself was well-portrayed, however, and seemed to stay true to Dr' Suess' original idea.Graphics/Sound: Good animation, but that should be expected in major animated motion pictures, these days. I will admit I didn't care for the style, though. Perhaps it is me speaking as a traditional animator, but I feel as though the entire movie would be a lot more powerful if it was hand-drawn, and not 3D computer graphics. The extremely tooney style and over-expression of characters makes me think it would have looked amazing, in 2D. The sound was good; particularly the voices. I have never been a big fan of DeVito, but he made for a very good Lorax. The music, however, left a lot to be desired. While I admit there was a catchiness to "How Bad Can I Be?" the Once-ler's song of self-justification, most of the musical numbers are extremely average.Message: While the message here is obviously the preservation of nature and protection of the environment, I wasn't sure I was completely swayed. As the child of a strong and accomplished environmentalist (and as a budding environmentalist myself), I have seen many, many movies with many, many environmental messages, and this one just didn't do it for me. In fact, at the end, O'Hare even gives a pretty damn good argument against. Had I been a resident of the town of Thneedsville, I might have stayed on his side, particularly since the town is all light and bright and beautiful, without a single plant. I mean, ants and bees? Who needs that? Without a solid argument promoting the importance of nature and human connection to the environment, I fail to see how everybody could suddenly burst into song.Conclusion: Meh. It was nothing special, and certainly didn't provide the powerful message that the original book and animation did. With the exception of a few humorous one-liners and visual antics, it was very forgetful. I applaud the developers for a rare environmental movie, but even this ended up being a let-down after hearing about and watching the notorious car add. What is the point of promoting important causes, if you are simply going to follow the hypocritical path of selling out, and you become a Once-ler, yourself? While I won't relate this action to the movie itself, it does say an awful lot about the people we put our faith in, in the entertainment industry. In short? Practice what you preach, in your mainstream B-grade family entertainment.

Review title: Good lessons, too political for young children
Review_body: My 3-year-old son and I saw this movie in the theater. It was quite entertaining and funny, although I have to say that there was a tad too many political overtones for a child to be exposed to.The movie is all about the importance of nature and planting trees - a lesson I FULLY agree with and support. However, there is a lengthy song-and-dance routine that paints a horrifying picture of greed and evil. While I believe it is important for children to learn these concepts early in life, I don't think they were very well-placed in this film at all. It could have been more subtle without taking anything away from the plot or film as a whole.Again, let me stress that I do not disagree with the positive message of the film, but rather the way the filmmakers chose to portray our country's politically liberal population as better and more compassionate than the contrasting conservative, right-wing population. This is a topic that is not meant for young children and it has no place in a film like this. These concepts are better debated and understood at a later age.

However a river did turn red in china this week and they don't know why...But I do live about 3 miles down a road that has a serious litter problem. Review_body: Make it totally awe-inspiring!Also I found the theater matters. We saw the Lorax at a smaller neighborhood theater that didn't play 45 minutes of previews before the actual movie starts! Review title: 11 Year Old and I (Dr. Seuss Fans) Loved It
Review_body: I can't believe (well, yes I can) that people gave this a bad review. I was afraid I was going to be disappointed when I saw the Lorax, based on some reviews, but I wasn't at all. My 11 year old and I both loved the movie, she laughed out loud at many parts (although I have to admit she does do that a lot watching movies) and we left very pleased that we saw it.Background: I grew up on Dr. Seuss, my six kids grew up with Dr. Seuss. We love Dr. Seuss even as adults. We've read the book, we've seen the original movie. I have two vegetarian older daughters, we are environmentally conscious. Also, we like musicals and my father was a music teacher - so finding out it was a musical was not a disappointment. There was definitely NOT a lot of musical numbers. If you hate musicals, I think the songs are infrequent enough that you can groan through it and let your kid enjoy the movie. That said, despite all the reviews on bad music, we thought the songs were lively and fun and cute. You're not gonna go out and buy a record for it, but it fit the movie for the kids it was targeted to.Like another reviewer said: THIS IS A MOVIE FOR KIDS!! As with any movie, it's geared toward a certain age group. People who take two-year olds to the theater must be crazy, taking them to see this movie is no exception. Granted, there's cute fuzzy bears, but there's a story being told and a lesson - definitely geared toward elementary/pre-teens, not the yo gabba gabba crowd. Your toddler or active pre-schooler will not sit through this.My opinion is also based on the fact that we do not watch a lot of movies or TV, (I'm a firm believer that kids should be outside playing), and we are certainly not film or animation connoisseurs. I can see how someone used to intense-graphics and action-packed films would get bored with this. It is a story. If you like kid stories, you will like this. We did not find it boring, I thought it was well told, and it held our interest all the way through.Is it like the original? There's a lot different, a little similar. I don't think I've ever seen a movie that was like the book. Book is always better. Contrary to what another reviewer said about no rhyming, there are rhymes and some book quotes in the movie.When they redid Cat in the Hat, I didn't like it, didn't like what they did with the Cat character at all, but my kids did. I liked The Lorax, and my daughter did. (The others are in college and haven't seen it yet...but they will I'm sure.) I'm somewhat sensitive to violence and scariness in movies (but not overly so), and I feel this is safe to take your kids to if they get scared easy. There's occasional moments when I had to roll my eyes up and think "did X really have to punch X at that moment" - but it's not violent or scary at all. Your kid won't go home with nightmares or shooting people. Maybe they'll even plant a tree.If you have elementary/pre-teen kids I highly recommend this movie for you and your kids.

Review title: Another Missed Opportunity and Awful Remake
Review_body: Not that anyone is surprised, but this is just another remake, as Hollywood and the world seem to be in a dramatic shortage of creative thinking, imagination, and originality. The graphics are pretty good, with the animals and the trees stealing the show. Rob Riggle has the best dialogue by far, with Betty White coming in second. That's right- their two ancillary characters are better-written than the Lorax himself. All other characters fall unremarkably flat except the undeniably adorable animals, which shine brighter than the majority of the cast without ever uttering a word other than in musical sections. This movie is of course a remake (or "reimagining" as producers and directors are so keen on calling schlock which is clearly a teardown ripoff of original material) of the 70s original based on the Dr. Seuss book. The message of the originals is an imperative one, that we need to treat our environment better than me do. In our own greed-driven and selfish quests for wealth, we tear down and kill everything in our way, choosing the easy route rather than having to make any kind of difficult decision- no matter who or what it hurts. I believe that Dr. Seuss meant his writing to make children care about the world around them so that we could have a better tomorrow, with less pollution and less carelessness. Unfortunately, this message is mostly lost in the 2012 version. Hollywood has, as per its usual lately, unzipped and dropped trow on Seuss's message. No longer is it a story of a boy who actually cares enough to ask why the world around him is deteriorating. No, now the boy (who has become at least 12 or 13 by the looks of it) is not really concerned at all, but only trying to find a tree so that he can get some action from the "hippie/activist girl" stereotype added into the movie. Neither of those characters are very compelling. The book was filled with dark and gloomy colors meant to show you the destruction caused by greedy consumerism and lack of concern about improving the environment. This movie downplays that, limiting the appearance of the wasteland outside of the newly-invented Thneedville to just a few scenes and opting to more frequently show flashbacks and the suburban world inside "the wall."As for the dialogue and music? This is a Dr. Seuss book, yet most of the dialogue doesn't even bother being clever enough to rhyme. (And by most, I mean virtually ALL but the music.) And speaking of the music- dear, sweet, unmerciful god- listening to the atrocities people call music in this music was like watching a snuff film but with my ears. I felt unclean after listening to them. 'How bad can they be?' SPOILER ALERT: PRETTY FREAKING BAD. On a press release, Universal said that this was so successful that they were going to make another Dr. Seuss book into a movie.... 'The Cat in the Hat.' First of all...... Hasn't that already been done in 2003 with Michael Myers??????? GO Hollywood! Way to remake a remake of a remake of a book. I can't wait for the 2015 of the remake of that remake. You know what they say in Hollywood: The fourteenth time's the charm. Secondly: PLEASE DON'T! You are just going to ruin another childhood memory of mine and many other like-minded people whose parents actually had the care to make them read as a child instead of sitting them in front of the TV.Parents, please. Show your children the classics. By buying crap to set your children down in front of the TV for an hour to get rid of them for, you are breeding a generation of uneducated sheep who have awful taste in music and treat the world even worse than every generation before it. Seriously, let them watch a dramatic 10 minute reading of the original on Youtube. They'll learn more than the hour and a half waste of time that this movie is.And in closing, to the other reviewer promoting the "Lorax Snuggie" saying how awesome it is? My point is illustrated by your post. That looks an awful lot like a Thneed to me.

Review title: A fantastic film with a great message
Review_body: This is a film not just for kids (but ours loved it). There is a great message for us all about how corporate greed is hurting us all and our planet. It would be funny if it weren't so true. Definitely some amazing filmmaking wrapped in a colorful and highly entertaining movie. The animation is really well done and the timing of the movie ensures that you will be entertained throughout. We have a seven and a nine year old and they both loved the film which prompted a family discussion about the evils about greedy corporations and the mistruths they spew onto an all to apathetic public. The film stays true to the Dr. Seuss legacy and reminds me why they have always been a favorite of mine from childhood until today. Do yourself a favor and watch it with your children!

Enclosed in the artificial town of Thneed-ville there lived a young twelve year-old boy, Ted (Zac Efron). Thneed-Ville is a 100% synthetic town. The air is sold as a product and nature is nowhere to be found. Thneed-ville swiftly changes because of Ted's sweetheart, Audrey (Taylor Swift). Audrey's biggest wish is to see a real tree, and Ted stops at nothing to make this happen. Visiting the Once-ler, he tells Ted the story of when he had become addicted to cutting down trees for money. All while ignoring the words of the guardian of the forest, "the Lorax". Ted becomes not only involved in finding Aubrey a tree, but decides to take a stand and speak for the trees. The children's book "The Lorax" originally written by Dr. Seuss has masterly been transformed into a motion picture. The lively colors and odd shaped objects create the vibe that Dr. Seuss is known for, but don't let the colors distract from its true meaning. "The Lorax" is a movie about saving the trees and being kind to nature. The theme man vs. nature is powerfully projected towards the viewers. The goal is to educate all ages about taking care of the world we have. The film makers didn't stop at just making this movie. Many foundations were formed to help prevent the loss of our world's trees. Hearing the name Dr. Seuss we automatically think of odd words that rhyme, bizarre shapes, and colors we never thought existed; therefore when creating this movie the animators had a huge palate to work with. Since Thneed-Ville was a manufactured city, the buildings and cars are futuristic and captivating. From the city to the forest, no words can describe the striking sight of the trees. Do your part in saving the tress and watch this highly recommend film, "The Lorax".

"The Lorax" is an amazing and adorable family movie that everyone should see! Many people have said that this movie is juvenile, stupid, and utterly disgusting but personally I loved it! I'm 13, and I still thought the animation was adorable, the moral was inspiring, and it even has one of my favorite singers! "The Lorax" is about a little 12 year old boy that lives in a town made of plastic. There is no life, no trees, no green! There is a girl that lives in his neighborhood that he likes very much. She hates the town of plastic and she longs to have one tree; one piece of life. The little boy goes on a scary adventure outside of the town to try and retrieve one tree for the girl he likes. To find the tree, he discovers the story of The Lorax, who is the protector of all of the living trees. This movie inspired me to take care of nature and to never give up. It was amazing!"The Lorax" has charming and amazing animation. The little boy Ted has brown hair and brown eyes. Ted is played by Zac Efron. The girl that Ted is in love with is named Audrey. She has long golden hair and green eyes. She is played by the amazing Taylor Swift! Danny DeVito plays the adorable Lorax! The Lorax is a little orange fur ball that guards the trees! Teds grandmother is played by Betty White. She is a small old lady with white hair. She plays an important role because she is the one that tell Ted where to find the tree! The last character is Mr.O'Hare. Mr.O'Hare is played by Rob Riggle. He plays the mean mayor of the plastic town and he does not want anyone to have life or anyone to find life! So he try's to stop Ted from finding a tree an bringing it back to Audrey. Even though this movie was adorable, inspiring, and amazing, it is a little juvenile. Some people don't like animation in movies and maybe that's why it got a terrible rating. Also, I thought that the actors could have did better. Zac Efron for example, could have been more enthusiastic is his role. Taylor Swift plays Audrey in the movie. Taylor is an OK actress but I think she should stick to singing. I love her but I don't think acting is her thing. However, the overall movie was amazing. "The Lorax" is a movie that everyone should see!There is not many bad things about this movie, but there is many good things. This movie is truly inspiring. It teaches you to never give up no matter what the circumstance is, and it also teaches you to never hurt nature and all living things. It teaches you to never give up, when Ted rides out of the plastic town many times to finish hearing the story if the Lorax, and he almost gets caught. He never gives up on trying to get a tree for Audrey. This movie also teaches you to never hurt nature. When the Lorax tells the story of how the trees disappeared, it makes you realize how sensitive and beautiful nature actually is.Ultimately, "The Lorax" is one of my favorite movies. I saw it with one of my best friends and we thought is was cute, funny, and inspiring. Everyone should see this movie no matter what age you are. I think this movie will teach kids many things about killing nature and never giving up on your dreams. I hope that the people that do not like this movie will change their minds because this movie is truly amazing.

Dr.Seuss once said, "Unless someone like you cares a whole awful lot, nothing is going to get better. It's not." This powerful quote comes one of my favorite animations, "The Lorax". The popular children's book was written in 1971. It came to the big screen in 2012 from the directors Kyle Balda and Chris Renaud. They are also the creators who directed "Despicable Me". Making around $70.2 million opening weekend, this colorful entertaining film that teaches a very important lesson.The story took place in a town called "Thneed-ville," which was a walled city, where everything was completely artificial, and the people even bought plastic containers of clean air. A young boy named Ted Wiggins (Zac Efron) fell for Audrey (Taylor Swift), whose dream was to see a real tree. After finding out where he could find one from his grandmother (Betty White), he bravely set out of town to try and grant Audrey's wish. Ted found the Once-ler (Ed Helms) outside of the city and listened to his story. The Once-ler was the reason why there were no more living trees. The Once-ler explained that when he cut down all the trees, he crossed paths with the Lorax (Danny DeVito), who didn't like human intruders. When Ted finally got along with the Once-ler after multiple visits, the Once-ler gave Ted a tree seed to take back to the city. Ted successfully took the seed back to the city and planted it, and he won Audrey by granting her wish.I believe that the directors, Kyle Balda and Chris Renaud, intended this film to be an environmentalist approach for children. Even though children are still young, they should still learn to care about the environment. This film shows the effects of environmental issues that we face every day in life. It teaches a lesson about why chopping trees down can be bad and how it can impact the world. At a young age, children don't realize what effect human have on the environment we live in. This film also makes it clear that if someone cares a lot about something, only good can happen out of it. Only good things will happen if someone decides to stand up and do what's right. This is one of my favorite animations by far. The bright bold colors make me feel happy. Being an animal lover, I also like how the animals give a cute and cuddly expression. The musical scenes make me want to join in and sing along because they are so catchy. I really hope that Universal Studios distributes more movies like this in the future. This movie was excellent overall, and I look forward to seeing more eye- catching films similar to "The Lorax".

Review title: a great way to explain important issues to your kid
Review_body: The film is based around the old Lorax cartoon. The short story included in the cartoon now forms up a center of the new animation.Some people liked the cartoon more, personally I think this new breath made it good. It stopped to be just a teaching experience, maybe even a bit pretentious. Now we're involved in the action and maybe just on the way we realize that there're some important things in the world. That we need to save the planet. Or we start asking ourselves where're we going in the tech industry (and does it make sense to produce fake trees producing oxygen).There're of course also such issues like being persistent, brave, able to stand out and fight for your dreams. That is really a cool set to talk about with your kids.
Big fan big fan! I love the grandma. Love this movie.

I finally had the chance to see it on Netflix. And I want an hour and a half of my summer back.CONS This movie is colorful and has candy everywhere. That's the reason kids wanted to see it. But the movie is filled with characters being hit with flying objects and getting hurt in some stupid silly way. After 9 minutes I saw it being stupidly obvious they were repeating the same comedy over and over to keep kids awake. The awful cheesy romance didn't come off as comedic like they wanted it to. It came off as annoying, and super awkward to watch. PROS There was 1 thing that made me laugh but I quickly forgot because of more terrible comedy following it.~Jimothy

Review title: A Disgrace to the Original Story
Review_body: This film is just dreadful. It is an embarrassment to the original story. For starters, the Onceler. The Onceler never showed his face as it showed it can happen to anybody and not just some hipster boy that makes pop culture references. He also showed sympathy to the Lorax originally but money and power corrupted him, not his relatives and a pop song. Another issue i have is The Lorax as he was supposed to be a kind-hearted pacifist who spoke for nature, not a violent Pop culture referencing... well, prick. they turned a Dr. Seuss classic into a corporate tool that won't stand the test of time (Oh and isn't the story kinda anti-corporation, kinda hypocritical to use him for a bunch of corporations, huh?)
Too much singing, trees are wack, anti vape?B.:(

If it wasn't for DD being in this, I would have gave it a lower score. Terrible songs, unappealing characters (at time difficult to look at) and I spent most of my time considering just how mediocre an actor Ed Helms is. Just a complete waste of time and kids would find it tedious.

Review title: Not sure what is wrong with some of you reviewers.
Review_body: This is a very good reimagining of The Lorax, completing the story where it is left off in the book. There are some very catchy songs and funny moments throughout, as well as the movie having very important messages within. Most kids films nowadays are mostly eye trash and very shallow. This movie isn't and has important lessons about consequences and change. Maybe they could have spent a little more time making the Lorax a little more of a part, but movies can only be so long.

Thought this might be a decent movie to see on big IMAX screen today. Visually was good, movie was not. It was a big meme about big bad corporations, kids will not recognize this fact though. For that matter most adults might not be able to either. Does not hold candle to other good animations, such as Toy Story, Up, etc.. that were actually good movies. I think I have made the point, not sure why I need to have 10 lines of text to make my statement. Guess this is the reason I do not bother with such things as helping people not waste their money on poor movies such as this one. All I need is just one more line of excellent comments and I have wasted 10 minutes on this review.
As many others I don't like it, because the message wasn't strong enough, but because it perfectly shows our future, I give 9.
